statement.text: The smallest directly measured masses in physics are those of elementary particles, with the electron mass (mₑ ≈ 9.109 × 10⁻³¹ kg) being the lightest charged particle and neutrinos having even smaller masses (<0.8 eV/c² ≈ 1.4 × 10⁻³⁶ kg). Modern mass spectrometers can detect individual atoms (~10⁻²⁵ kg), while Penning traps achieve fractional precision of 10⁻¹¹ on electron mass. The Planck mass (2.18 × 10⁻⁸ kg) is NOT the smallest—it's actually ~10²² times larger than electron mass.
statement.formal: Smallest measured: m_ν < 0.8 eV/c² ≈ 1.4 × 10⁻³⁶ kg; mₑ = 9.1093837015(28) × 10⁻³¹ kg; Detection limit: ~1 atom ≈ 10⁻²⁵ kg

explanation.intuition: While the Planck mass sets a natural scale for quantum gravity, it's actually quite 'large' at ~22 micrograms (visible dust speck). The truly smallest masses are elementary particles: electrons, quarks, and especially neutrinos. Mass detection limits depend on the technology—individual atoms can be trapped and weighed, individual electrons can be measured with 10⁻¹¹ precision.
explanation.key_insight: There are THREE distinct concepts: (1) Smallest mass of known particles (neutrinos, <10⁻³⁶ kg), (2) Smallest mass detectable by current technology (single atoms ~10⁻²⁵ kg with full precision, individual particles with less precision), (3) Theoretical mass resolution limits from quantum mechanics (zero-point motion in traps). The Planck mass is NOT a minimum—it's a scale where quantum gravity becomes important.
explanation.technical_details: Penning trap mass measurements achieve δm/m ~ 10⁻¹¹ for electrons. For heavy ions, δm ~ 10⁻³⁹ kg absolute resolution. Single-ion optical clocks can detect mass changes from nuclear excitation. Gravitational wave detectors (LIGO) are sensitive to mass displacements but not direct mass measurement. The KATRIN experiment measures neutrino mass via β-decay kinematics, setting m_ν < 0.8 eV/c² (2022).
theoretical_limits: Quantum zero-point motion in traps sets noise floor
Gravitational decoherence may limit mass superpositions
No known minimum mass in Standard Model (massless photons, gluons)

comparison_with_planck.interpretation: Planck mass is a 'large' mass compared to particles—it represents where gravitational self-energy equals rest mass, NOT a minimum measurable mass

atom_trap.description: Optical or magnetic trapping of neutral atoms

detection_capabilities.macro_objects: down to ~10⁻⁹ kg with precision balances

related.relationship: Planck mass is NOT minimum—it's 10²² times larger than electron mass

sources.citation: KATRIN Collaboration (2022): Direct neutrino-mass measurement with sub-electronvolt sensitivity
Blaum, K. (2006): High-accuracy mass spectrometry with stored ions

learning_objectives: Distinguish between Planck mass and minimum measurable mass
Understand that Planck mass is LARGE compared to particles
Know the hierarchy of particle masses from neutrinos to protons
common_misconceptions: Planck mass is NOT the smallest mass—it's ~22 micrograms, quite large
There is no 'minimum mass' in physics—photons and gluons are massless
Mass measurement limits depend on technology, not fundamental physics (below Planck scale)
